question: Question_02_(c)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answer and \textbf{show all
your work.} Simplification of the answer is not required.

Find the length of the curve

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
y = x^2 - \frac{\ln x}8, \quad\text{for } 1\leq x \leq 2.\end{align*}
sols:
Using the formula in the hint, we see that we require the derivative of
the curve in question. Notice that

\begin{align*}\frac{dy}{dx} = 2x - \frac{1}{8x}\end{align*}

and so we compute the arc length to be

\begin{align*}
\int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx &= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + \left(2x - \frac{1}{8x} \right)^{2}} \, dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + 4x^{2} - \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{64x^{2}}} \, dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{4x^{2} + \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{64x^{2}}} \, dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{(2x + \frac{1}{8x})^{2}} \, dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{2}(2x + \frac{1}{8x}) \, dx \\
&= \left.(x^{2} + \frac{1}{8}\ln|x|)\right|_{1}^{2} \\
&= (2)^{2} + \frac{1}{8}\ln(2) - (1)^{2} - \frac{1}{8}\ln(1)\\
&= 3 + \frac{1}{8}\ln(2).\end{align*}
hints:
The formula for the arc length of this curve on the interval from
$1 \leq x \leq 2$ is

$\int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx.$
